awd_titl_txt: Molecules in Non-Perturbative Fields: Improving Time-Dependent Density Functional Approximations and Electron-Ion Correlation Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Neepa Maitra of CUNY Hunter College is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry to develop theoretical and computational approaches for simulating the correlated dynamics of electrons and ions.  The Condensed Matter and Materials program in the Division of Materials Research also contributes to this award. Understanding the motion of electrons and ions is important for understanding and predicting many phenomena that involve the interaction of matter with light.  These phenomena have both fundamental and technical importance, for example, photovoltaic devices which convert light into electricity, photocatalysis, and control of chemical processes using lasers.   The equation that governs this motion has been known for 90 years.    For all but the simplest systems, however, it is too difficult to solve this equation exactly.  This difficulty arises because of correlated motion. Each electron's motion affects every other electron's motion as well as each ion's, and vice-versa.  Time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) is an efficient, approximate and popular approach to solving this equation.  In many cases, the particular approximations used today are not adequate, causing unpredictable errors in the electron dynamics.  Maitra and her coworkers develop improved approximations based on rigorous theoretical considerations.  Both undergraduate and graduate students participate in this cutting-edge research. Maitra organizes mini-workshops at CUNY open to scientists in the wider New York area.  She works with existing   programs at Hunter College to promote the development of underrepresented minority scientists

 Maitra and her coworkers develop improved, robust approximations for electron dynamics by imposing exact conditions, so that the theory can be used for real-time dynamics with as much confidence and predictability as density functional theory is used for ground-state energies and structures.   The goals is to overcome several limitations of TDDFT that currently prevent it from being used reliably for real-time electron dynamics in the non-perturbative regime, as well as for excitation spectra.  The dynamics of the electrons and ions are coupled by using a method based on the recently-introduced first-principles exact factorization approach.   This includes developing practical mixed quantum-(semi)classical schemes for correlated electron-ion dynamics that include electronic decoherence and wave packet-branching from first-principles.

por.por_cntn:
Accurate theoretical and computational modeling of the time-resolved dynamics of molecules remains a challenge today, yet an important one that impacts an increasingly wide range of applications, from photovoltaic design to the control of chemical reactions using laser fields. This project advanced time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) to treat the electron dynamics, while developing the exact factorization (EF) approach for a first-principles treatment of correlated electron-ion motion. TDDFT is a method of choice for electronic excitations and dynamics of molecules due to its favorable system-size scaling however the approximate functionals used today have been found to perform poorly for some applications, particularly for when the system is driven significantly away from a ground-state. Our work revealed specific reasons for this failure, for example for charge-transfer dynamics and electron-ion scattering,  and in doing so, pointed to a new approach for functional development that should correct the problems of the usual approximations. We developed the density-matrix coupled exchange-correlation functionals, which we showed captured some of the effects missing in the traditional approximations, but more work is needed since it runs into stability problems at relatively short times. 

The electron dynamics is strongly coupled to the nuclear dynamics, and to develop a consistent and general scheme that can capture their correlated dynamics, we turned to the recently proposed EF approach which provides potentials and forces acting on each subsystem that contains the effects of the other exactly. The project examined a mixed quantum-classical method based on EF and elucidated the terms which are essential to give wave packet branching and decoherence, possibly pointing to some simplifications of the algorithm in future developments. We also solved the EF equations self-consistently, and investigated their numerical stability properties for the first time, which is useful when developing approximations to them. We extended the EF to systems of coupled electrons, nuclei, and photons, in order to address problems in the burgeoning field of polaritonic chemistry. Here, molecules are placed in nano- or mesoscale cavities which can greatly enhance the light-matter coupling, such that their properties can be manipulated even without any input power. We showed how the EF provides the correct cavity-modified potential energy surfaces that dictate the dynamics of the molecule, as well as the effective potential that drives the photonic dynamics. This brings some completely new concepts to the field of polaritonic chemistry that yield fundamental insight as well as the starting point for new practical simulation methods. 

The project led to the training of some excellent postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates. People from groups traditionally under-represented in the sciences were involved in  research, and exposed to a large scientific community working through their participation in local, national, and international workshops and conferences. Pre-meeting tutorials at APS were given by the PI on TDDFT, as well as pedagogical talks at several DFT and other theory schools. The PI co-organized a US-based School and Workshop on TDDFT attended by more than 30 graduate students largely from the US, and also from outside the US, which was extremely successful from both the scientific and community points of view.
